fields.description:
I added full control access to a bucket  in ui-test-acct-00 to ui-test-acct-01 by using account ID of ui-test-acct-01. However, I could not see the the bucket from ui-test-acct-01. Screenshots included. 

We should add a message explaining to the user that shared bucket will not be visible.
fields.summary: Allow a user to browse a shared bucket and download shared objects

comments.body: I suggest testing on AWS since we can use the AWS console to verify ACLs.

I installed s3cmd on 10.111.5.12 and shared a bucket from the ui-test-acct-02 with eucalyptus/admin.  When I run 's3cmd ls' (as the euca/admin acct), the shared bucket isn't listed.

{code}
[root@h-12 ~]# s3cmd ls
2015-01-17 10:55  s3://imaging-worker-v1
2015-01-17 10:53  s3://loadbalancer-v1
2015-01-17 11:00  s3://precise-server-cloudimg-amd64-disk1img
2015-01-23 20:37  s3://vic_kvm_image
{code}

Steps to reproduce...
1. Share a bucket from the ui-test-acct-02 with the eucalyptus/admin account (full control) in the console, using account ID 453485424274 for the eucalyptus/admin account, on clchost 10.111.5.12.
2. SSH into 10.111.5.12 as root
3. Run 's3cmd ls' (uses config file at /root/.s3cfg)

[~zhill], [~wwannemacher], [~swathi]: Is there anything else that needs to be considered when listing a bucket that has been shared from one account to another?  Bucket and/or IAM policies?
Notes for installing s3cmd for Eucalyptus are at https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucalyptus/wiki/HowTo-use-s3cmd-with-Eucalyptus

Shared buckets never show up in a bucket listing. Only buckets owned by the account doing the listing are included. To use a shared bucket you must specifically know the name and address it individually.
[~zhill] thanks for explaining this.    [~kgill] I saw the ACL show up correctly in s3cmd for the shared bucket.
[~alice]: Understood.  Should we close this ticket and mark as "not a bug", perhaps after updating the title to "Sharing buckets between accounts does not list the bucket in the shared account"?

[~kgill] yes, let's change the name of the ticket. [~jloza] We should add some sort of a message for the user to explain that the shared bucket will not be visible from console. If this was not obvious to me, other users might run into this too.

yeah this seems like a pretty big UX fail that we should try and address. [~zhill], is there a way the user can see the bucket? How do they "address" it? Can we do something in the console that will allow buckets to be seen by those they are shared with but who do not own them (a dialog to enter the bucket name or something and then we can connect to it and display it, perhaps)?

We should look at ways to make this improvement in 4.2.

I don't know how the AWS console does it. For API requests you just specify the bucket to list or get/put objects directly. The most common usage for shared buckets is for getting data for websites etc.

I think a "browse shared bucket" button would work that lets the user enter a bucket name. Also, it is possible to share data objects without he bucket itself so a user can download an object but not list the bucket contents.

I checked the AWS console, and it doesn't have any way to browse shared buckets at all.

We should also note that the way permissions in the ACLs and IAM are setup there are several different behaviors that can result that might be confusing to users:

1. The "list contents of bucket" ACL permission is distinct from the ability to interact (upload or download) objects themselves. (READ on the bucket but not READ on any objects)

2. Users may be granted the ability to upload but not list the contents of the bucket or even read any data from the bucket. (WRITE on the bucket but not READ on any objects)

3. Users may be granted access to download specific objects but not list the contents of the bucket or upload new objects to the bucket (no ACL perms on the bucket, but READ access on a set of objects)

The only way a user can tell what is going on is if they are also granted ACL permissions (READACL on the bucket and/or objects) so that they can see what the settings are. It is extremely rare and dangerous to grant such permissions to another account since there are billing implications to S3 usage in AWS.

This is probably just content to put in a "help" window on the "View shared bucket" dialog or something, but it's worth noting for our testing and evaluation purposes.

We should include help that explains why they may not see shared buckets on the other account.

we could also provide the user a way to get at buckets they don't see... enter a bucket name in a dialog?

New feature issues do not track story points- We should consider adding a Story as a sub-task and tracking that through the sprint. We can discuss further and see what our options are. Story points: 5
Added icon to use in buckets landing page, table view, for shared bucket.

A complication of using LocalStorage vs cookies to store saved shared buckets is that LocalStorage isn't specific to a single cloud/account, as the shared bucket is. We'll need to include those items in the key name.

todos
 - split grey line should be same as border (done)
 - disable dialog button till required input is there (done)
 - add shared buckets to dash bucket total. (done)
 - hover for split secondary button (arrow) should go blue (sort of, line blue, but arrow not)
 - bubble help not working for download object dialog (done, but not data-tooltip)
 - download should not open another tab. (done)
 - object upload to shared should accept only bucket name. Validation error should not be italic. (done)
 - test contents features while in shared bucket. (done)

https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucaconsole/pull/1438

I addressed concerns from our review w/ possible exception of split arrow, but it seems consistent w/ how primary split hover behaves (in that arrow remains same color during hover)

Let me know if there are any other things to tweak.

Thanks, [~dkavanagh], looking great! A couple of minor things:

* validation error style should not turn the associated widget label red. If you see those elsewhere in the code, please fie a bug so we can correct them for consistency. If you want to see the right class to apply for validation errors, check step 3 of the launch instance wizard. 
* help bubble text does not have the right class applied. See other help bubbles for the right classes.

The help bubble suffers from the same issue as on stack-wizard. I had to use native tooltip, vs the foundation one. Maybe [~kgill] has an idea, but I couldn't figure it out.
I fixed the validation red label by removing the "for" attribute on the labels. Abide sees that and adds the "error" class to the label as well. Using "for" helps with accessibility, so we may wish to alter the abide error styling for labels.

[~dkavanagh]: I had some issues with Foundation tooltips for elements that are initially hidden (e.g. expandos) while working on GUI-1486, so I created an AngularJS utility method at https://github.com/eucalyptus/eucaconsole/blob/master/eucaconsole/static/js/pages/eucaconsole_utils.js#L85-L100 
Hopefully that works for you.

/cc [~jloza]
kicking back to try the tooltip thing Kamal mentioned!
I planned on fixing that once that branch merged since I saw the fix when I did code review... anyway, done now.

Yay, nice job, [~dkavanagh]! 

UX review passed, ready for code review.
curly braces fixed in 4 places. Good to go now?
PR 1438 merged

[~dkavanagh]: What exactly do I need to test here?  The bug title does not seem to reflect what was 'fixed'.  It seems that the conclusion was made that AWS does not allow buckets between accounts to be listed from the buckets page.  Is this still correct or am I missing something?

We didn't directly address the original complaint. The fact that shared (and unknown) buckets are not visible is just a fact of life. We added features to allow a user to browse a shared bucket and download shared objects.
[~dkavanagh] Not sure how to verify this, may need some help walking thru it.

[~ashamblin], you can login as 1 account, share a bucket, then share an object with the world, or a single account via the sharing panel.
Then, login as another user (or a specific one based on what sharing you used) and use the options in the landing page ("Open Shared Bucket", "Download Object")

Tested on Shared Setup #1

Created a bucket with view/download rights to authenticated users.  Logged into second account and was able to access the bucket and download contents.
Released in 4.2
